title: Steve Miller Band
text:
{{Short description|American rock band}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Steve Miller Band |image = Steve Miller Band Ravinia.jpg |caption = Steve Miller Band in 2009 |image_size = 250 |landscape = Yes |background = group_or_band |alias = The Steve Miller Blues Band
The Miller Band |origin = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], U.S. |genre = {{flatlist| *[[Rock music|Rock]] *[[blues rock]]{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=steve-miller-band-mn0000036106}} *[[psychedelic rock]]{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/20-albums-rolling-stone-loved-in-the-sixties-that-youve-never-heard-20140522/steve-miller-band-children-of-the-future-19691231 | title=20 Albums Rolling Stone Loved in the Sixties That You've Never Heard | publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] | access-date=9 April 2015}} *[[Southern rock]]{{cite web | url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?name=The+Steve+Miller+Band | title=Steve Miller Band | publisher=robertchristgau.com | access-date=9 April 2015 | author=Christgau, Robert | author-link=Robert Christgau }} *[[rock and roll]]}} |years_active = 1966–present |label = {{flatlist| *[[Capitol Records|Capitol]] *[[Mercury Records|Mercury]] *[[Polydor]] *[[Roadrunner Records|Roadrunner]] *Loud & Proud}} |associated_acts = Goldberg-Miller Blues band, [[Boz Scaggs]] |website = [http://www.stevemillerband.com/ www.stevemillerband.com] |current_members = * [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]] * Kenny Lee Lewis * [[Joseph Wooten]] * Jacob Petersen * Ron Wikso | past_members = {{Collapsible list |framestyle=border:none; padding:0; |title=  |[[Sonny Charles]] |Lonnie Turner |James Cooke |[[Tim Davis (musician)|Tim Davis]] |Jim Peterman |[[Boz Scaggs]] |[[Ben Sidran]] |[[Nicky Hopkins]] |[[Bobby Winkelman]] |[[Jack King (musician)|Jack King]] |[[Ross Valory]] |[[Gerald Johnson (musician)|Gerald Johnson]] |Dick Thompson |Roger Allen Clark |[[Gary Mallaber]] |John King |[[David Denny (musician)|David Denny]] |[[Greg Douglass]] |Byron Allred |[[Norton Buffalo]] |[[John Massaro (guitarist)|John Massaro]] |[[Billy Peterson]] |Ricky Peterson |Bob Malach |Gordy Knudtson }} }} The '''Steve Miller Band''' is an American [[rock music|rock]] band formed in 1966 in [[San Francisco]], [[California]].{{cite web | title = Steve Miller Band | publisher = Rateyourmusic.com | url = http://rateyourmusic.com/artist/steve_miller_band | access-date = 2008-11-13 }} The band is led by [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]] on [[guitar]] and lead vocals. The group had a string of mid- to late-1970s hit singles that are staples of [[classic rock]], as well as several earlier [[psychedelic rock]] albums. Miller left his first band to move to San Francisco and form the Steve Miller Blues Band. Shortly after Harvey Kornspan negotiated the band's contract with [[Capitol Records]] in 1967, the band shortened its name to the Steve Miller Band. In February 1968, the band recorded its debut album, ''[[Children of the Future (Steve Miller Band album)|Children of the Future]]''. It went on to produce the albums ''[[Sailor (album)|Sailor]]'', ''[[Brave New World (Steve Miller Band album)|Brave New World]]'', ''[[Your Saving Grace]]'', ''[[Number 5 (Steve Miller Band album)|Number 5]]'', ''[[Rock Love]]'', ''[[Fly Like an Eagle (album)|Fly Like an Eagle]]'', ''[[Book of Dreams]]'', among others. The band's ''[[Greatest Hits 1974–78]]'', released in 1978, sold over 13 million copies. In 2016, Steve Miller was inducted as a solo artist in the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. ==History== [[Image:Steve Miller Interlochen.jpg|thumb|Steve Miller performing at [[Interlochen Center for the Arts#Interlochen Arts Camp|Interlochen Fine Arts Camp]] on July 20, 2009]] In 1965, after moving to Chicago to play the [[blues]], Steve Miller and keyboardist [[Barry Goldberg]] founded the Goldberg-Miller Blues Band along with bassist Roy Ruby, rhythm guitarist Craymore Stevens, and drummer Maurice McKinley. The band contracted to [[Epic Records]] and recorded a single, "The Mother Song", which they performed on ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]'', before Miller left the group and moved to San Francisco.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uy6aKA1rTrEC&pg=PR48-IA23|page=xiviii|title=Crossroads: How the Blues Shaped Rock 'n' Roll|author=John Milward|publisher=UPNE|date= 2013|isbn=9781555537449}}{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/goldberg-miller-blues-band-1965-66-mw0000593963|work=allmusic.com|author=Lindsay Planer|title=Barry Goldberg / The Goldberg-Miller Blues Band Goldberg-Miller Blues Band 1965-66}} Miller then formed The Steve Miller Blues Band. Harvey Kornspan, managing partner, wrote and negotiated the band's contract ($860,000 over five years as well as $25,000 of promotion money that was to be spent at the band's discretion) with Capitol/[[EMI|EMI Records]] then-president [[Alan W. Livingston|Alan Livingston]] in 1967. Shortly after, the band's name was shortened to The Steve Miller Band at the recommendation of [[George Martin]] in order to broaden its appeal. The band, consisting of Miller, guitarist James Cooke, bassist Lonnie Turner, drummer [[Tim Davis (musician)|Tim Davis]] (who replaced the departing Lance Haas on drums) and Jim Peterman on Hammond B3 organ, backed [[Chuck Berry]] at a gig at the [[The Fillmore|Fillmore Auditorium]] that was released as the live album, ''[[Live at the Fillmore Auditorium (Chuck Berry album)|Live at Fillmore Auditorium]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chuckberry.us/wolfgangsvault.html |title=Chuck Berry News |publisher=Chuckberry.us |access-date=2014-08-23}} Guitarist [[Boz Scaggs]] joined the band soon after and the group performed at the [[Fantasy Fair and Magic Mountain Music Festival|Magic Mountain Festival]] (festival was held June 10/11, 1967) and the following week at the [[Monterey Pop Festival]] (festival was held June 16/17/18, 1967). In March 1968, while in England, the band recorded their debut album, ''[[Children of the Future (Steve Miller Band album)|Children of the Future]]'', at Olympic studios with [[Glyn Johns]] as engineer/producer. The album did not score among the Top 100 album chart. The visit itself got off to a poor start also as the group and their entourage were arrested for 'importing drugs and possession of a dangerous firearm'. Kornspan's wife had called Johns asking if he would appear as a character witness in the magistrate's court the day after the arrest and, hopefully, stand bail for them. Johns agreed and the group was released on condition that Johns would 'stand surety for their good behavior' for the rest of their time in England. Both accusations were dropped. The 'dangerous firearm' turned out to be a non-working flare gun that was being used as a wall decoration in the house where the group was staying. The 'imported drugs' happened to be some hash that was buried in the middle of a large fruitcake that had been sent to the group by a stateside friend, totally unbeknownst to anyone in the group.{{cite book |last1=Johns |first1=Glyn |title=Sound Man |date=2015 |publisher=Plume |location=New York |isbn=978-0-14-751657-2 |pages=98-103 |edition=First}} The second album ''[[Sailor (album)|Sailor]]'' appeared in October 1968 and climbed the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' chart to {{thinspace|No.| 24}}. Successes included the single "Living in the USA." ''[[Brave New World (Steve Miller Band album)|Brave New World]]'' ({{thinspace|No.| 22}}, 1969) featured the songs "Space Cowboy" and "My Dark Hour". [[Paul McCartney]], credited as "Paul Ramon", played drums, bass and sang backing vocals on "My Dark Hour". This was followed by ''[[Your Saving Grace]]'' ({{thinspace|No.| 38}}, 1969) and ''[[Number 5 (Steve Miller Band album)|Number 5]]'' ({{thinspace|No.| 23}}, 1970). In 1971, Miller broke his neck in a car accident. Capitol Records released the album ''[[Rock Love]]'', featuring unreleased live performances and studio material. This is one of two Steve Miller Band albums not to be released on CD, the other being ''[[Recall the Beginning...A Journey from Eden]]''. In 1972, the double album compilation ''[[Anthology (Steve Miller Band album)|Anthology]]'' was released, containing 16 songs from the band's first six of seven albums. The style and personnel of the band changed radically with ''[[The Joker (album)|The Joker]]'' ({{thinspace|No.| 1}}, 1973), concentrating on straightforward rock and leaving the psychedelic blues side of the band behind. The title track, "[[The Joker (Steve Miller Band song)|The Joker]]", became a {{thinspace|No.| 1}} single and was certified platinum, reaching over one million sales. It was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] on January 11, 1974.{{cite book| first= Joseph| last= Murrells| year= 1978| title= The Book of Golden Discs| edition= 2nd| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd| location= London| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/332 332]| isbn= 0-214-20512-6| url-access= registration| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/332}} Three years later, the band returned with the album ''[[Fly Like an Eagle (album)|Fly Like an Eagle]]'', which charted at {{thinspace|No.| 3}}. Three singles were released from the album: "[[Take the Money and Run (Steve Miller Band song)|Take the Money and Run]]" ({{thinspace|No.| 11}}), "[[Fly Like an Eagle (song)|Fly Like an Eagle]]" ({{thinspace|No.| 2}}) and their second {{thinspace|No.| 1}} success, "[[Rock'n Me]]". Miller credits the guitar introduction to "Rock'n Me" as a tribute to the [[Free (band)|Free]] song, "[[All Right Now]]".{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PgGqNrqfrsoC&q=%22yeah+it%27s+a+tack+on+the+wall+for+Paul%22&pg=PT456 | title=Billboard book of number 1 hits | isbn=9780823076772 | last1=Bronson | first1=Fred | year=2003 }} ''[[Book of Dreams (Steve Miller Band album)|Book of Dreams]]'' ({{thinspace|No.| 2}}, 1977) also included three successes: "[[Jet Airliner (Steve Miller Band song)|Jet Airliner]]" ({{thinspace|No.| 8}}), "[[Jungle Love (Steve Miller Band song)|Jungle Love]]" ({{thinspace|No.| 23}}) (later becoming the song played over the opening credits of the 8th season of the sitcom ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]''), and "Swingtown" ({{thinspace|No.| 17}}). 1982's ''[[Abracadabra (Steve Miller Band album)|Abracadabra]]'' album gave Steve Miller his third {{thinspace|No.| 1}} success with [[Abracadabra (Steve Miller Band song)|the title track]]. Miller's hit pushed [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]]'s "[[Hard to Say I'm Sorry]]" out of the {{thinspace|No.| 1}} spot, just as his "Rock'n Me" had knocked Chicago's "[[If You Leave Me Now]]" out of the {{thinspace|No.| 1}} spot in 1976. Released in 1978, ''The Steve Miller Band's Greatest Hits 1974–78'' has sold over 13 million copies.{{cite web |author=Jake Grove |url=http://www.independentmail.com/news/2008/oct/15/steve-miller-band-hits-littlejohn-clemson/ |title=The Steve Miller Band hits Littlejohn in Clemson |publisher=Independent Mail |date=2008-10-15 |access-date=2014-08-23 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116201440/http://www.independentmail.com/news/2008/oct/15/steve-miller-band-hits-littlejohn-clemson/ |archive-date=2014-01-16 }} ''[[Bingo! (Steve Miller Band album)|Bingo!]]'', an album of blues and [[rhythm and blues|R&B]] covers, was released on June 15, 2010. ''[[Let Your Hair Down (album)|Let Your Hair Down]]'', a companion release to ''Bingo!'', was released 10 months later, on April 18, 2011.{{cite web |url=http://planetrock.com/newscentre/rock-news/steve-miller-band-announce-new-album-1463 |title=Steve Miller Band announce new album |publisher=Planet Rock |date=2011-02-11 |access-date=2011-12-30 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215033644/http://www.planetrock.com/newscentre/rock-news/steve-miller-band-announce-new-album-1463 |archive-date=2011-02-15 }} Founding member Tim Davis died from complications due to diabetes on September 20, 1988, at the age of 44. Long-time band member [[Norton Buffalo]] died from [[lung cancer]] on October 30, 2009. John King (drummer during "The Joker" era) died after a short bout with [[kidney cancer]] on October 26, 2010. James Cooke died from cancer on 16 May 2011. Original bassist Lonnie Turner died from lung cancer on April 28, 2013. His time with the band led to songs such as Jet Airliner, Swingtown, Take the Money And Run, Jungle Love and many more. Blues guitarist Jacob Peterson officially joined the band before the Spring 2011 tour. Following Petersen joining the band, longtime guitarist Kenny Lee Lewis switched instruments to become the band's full-time bassist. In 2014, Steve Miller Band toured with fellow San Francisco rock band [[Journey (band)|Journey]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stevemillerband.com |title=Steve Miller Band Official Site |publisher=Stevemillerband.com |date=2014-05-18 |access-date=2014-08-23}} ==Members== '''Current members''' * [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]] – lead vocals, guitar, harmonica, keyboards (1966–present) * Kenny Lee Lewis – guitar (1982–1983, 1987–1988, 1994–2011), bass (1983–1987, 2011–present), backing vocals (1982–1988, 1994–present) * [[Joseph Wooten]] – keyboards, backing vocals (1993–present) * Jacob Peterson – guitar, backing vocals (2011–present) * Ron Wikso – drums (2021–present) '''Former members''' * Lonnie Turner – bass, guitar, backing vocals (1966–1970, 1973–1978, died 2013) * [[Boz Scaggs]] – guitar, backing vocals (1967–1968) * Jim Peterman – keyboards, backing vocals (1966–1968) * [[Tim Davis (musician)|Tim Davis]] – drums, backing vocals (1966–1970, died 1988) * James "Curley" Cooke – guitar (1967, died 2011) * [[Ben Sidran]] – keyboards (1968, 1969, 1970, 1972, 1987–1991) * [[Nicky Hopkins]] – keyboards (1969, 1970; died 1994) * [[Bobby Winkelman]] – bass, guitar, backing vocals (1969–1970) * [[Ross Valory]] – bass, backing vocals (1970–1971) * Roger Allen Clark – drums (1972) * Jack King – drums (1970–1973) * Dick Thompson – keyboards (1972–1974) * Gary Mallaber – drums, keyboards, backing vocals (1976–1987) * Gerald Johnson – bass, backing vocals (1972–1973, 1981–1983) * John King – drums (1973–1974, died 2010) * [[Les Dudek]] – guitar (1975) * [[Doug Clifford]] – drums (1975) * [[Greg Douglass]] – slide guitar, backing vocals (1976–1978) * [[David Denny (musician)|David Denny]] – guitar, backing vocals (1976–1978) * Byron Allred – keyboards (1976–1987, 1990, died 2021) * John Massaro – guitar, backing vocals (1982–1983) * [[Norton Buffalo]] – harmonica, guitar, backing vocals (1976–1978, 1982–1987, 1989–2009, died 2009) * [[Billy Peterson]] – bass, backing vocals (1987–2011) * Bob Mallach – saxophone (1987–1996) * Paul Peterson – guitar (1988, 1991–1992) * Ricky Peterson – keyboards (1988, 1991) * Keith Allen – guitar, backing vocals (1989–1990) * [[Sonny Charles]] – backing vocals (2008–2011) * Gordy Knudtson – drums (1987–2021) ===Timeline===

==Discography== {{Main|Steve Miller Band discography}} ;Studio albums The group has been releasing albums and singles since 1968 and currently has released 18 [[studio album]]s, six [[live album]]s, seven (official) [[compilation album]]s, and at least 29 [[single (music)|single]]s. * ''[[Children of the Future (Steve Miller Band album)|Children of the Future]]'' (1968) * ''[[Sailor (album)|Sailor]]'' (1968) * ''[[Brave New World (Steve Miller Band album)|Brave New World]]'' (1969) * ''[[Your Saving Grace]]'' (1969) * ''[[Number 5 (Steve Miller Band album)|Number 5]]'' (1970) * ''[[Rock Love]]'' (1971) * ''[[Recall the Beginning...A Journey from Eden]]'' (1972) * ''[[The Joker (album)|The Joker]]'' (1973) * ''[[Fly Like an Eagle (album)|Fly Like an Eagle]]'' (1976) * ''[[Book of Dreams]]'' (1977) * ''[[Circle of Love (Steve Miller Band album)|Circle of Love]]'' (1981) * ''[[Abracadabra (Steve Miller Band album)|Abracadabra]]'' (1982) * ''[[Italian X Rays]]'' (1984) * ''[[Living in the 20th Century]]'' (1986) * ''[[Born 2 B Blue]]'' (1988) * ''[[Wide River]]'' (1993) * ''[[Bingo! (Steve Miller Band album)|Bingo!]]'' (2010) * ''[[Let Your Hair Down (album)|Let Your Hair Down]]'' (2011) ==Awards== [[File:Steve Miller Walk Fame.jpg|thumb|Receiving their Walk of Fame star.]] * [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers|ASCAP]] Golden Note Award, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/press/2008/0306_popawards.aspx |title=ASCAP to Honor Steve Miller and Lionel Richie at 25th Annual Pop Music Awards |publisher=Ascap.com |access-date=2014-08-23}} * Star for "Recording" on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] on 1750 [[Vine Street]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1675259/bio|title=Steve Miller Band|website=IMDb|access-date=2016-06-14}}{{Cite web|url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/the-steve-miller-band/|title=The Steve Miller Band|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-06-14}} * Steve Miller inducted into [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame|The Rock and Roll Hall Of Fame]] in 2016 {{cite web|url=https://rockhall.com/inductees/steve-miller/|title=Steve Miller|website=Rock & Roll Hall of Fame}} ==See also== * [[List of bands from the San Francisco Bay Area]] ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.stevemillerband.com/}} {{Steve Miller Band}} {{Boz Scaggs}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:American blues rock musical groups]] [[Category:American pop rock music groups]] [[Category:American musical trios]] [[Category:Capitol Records artists]] [[Category:Mercury Records artists]] [[Category:Polydor Records artists]] [[Category:Roadrunner Records artists]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1966]] [[Category:Musical groups from San Francisco]] [[Category:Psychedelic rock music groups from California]]
